Economics:

- Replenishment: there is an opportunity for ordering new product into the system. For direct shipments from vendor to store, the retailer is deciding whether to purchase the product, so the cost of that product is not a sunk cost like with allocation. Similarly, with DC fulfillment, its reasonable to assume that any unit sent from the DC to a selling location will be replaced at the DC.Since each unit replenished involves purchase of a unit, the benefit from a sales is the unit margin, not the unit price. This is based on cover period margin since any margin achieved after that could be equally attainable from a later order.Another consequence of bringing new inventory into the system is that the capital required to procure that inventory is now tied up until the product sells. Additionally, inventory must be handled and maintained

ntory is now tied up until the product sells. Additionally, inventory must be handled and maintained. These can be combined into an all-encompassing inventory carrying cost, which is proportional to the cost of the product and the time product is held/unsold. Therefore, any margin benefit will be offset by this cost.Some replenishment products may also have shelf lives after which the product much be discarded or sold off at a deep discount. The expected obsolescence cost from any new units should also be deducted from the benefit.

iscount. The expected obsolescence cost from any new units should also be deducted from the benefit.
- Allocation: for allocation, a basic assumption is that no additional rebuys will take place. The only inventory available for sales through the exit date is whatever is either on-hand or in the pipeline. All of this existing inventory is a sunk cost.Unlike with replenishment, the goal should be to maximize revenue from the existing inventory position. Thus, the benefit for sending a product is based on its unit price. Like with replenishment, the benefit is only evaluated for the cover period since post-CP revenue could be captured if the decision to send a unit is deferred until the next allocation.We may also wish to deduct any stranded cost for shipped product that doesnt sell (e.g., cost of shipping back).

h to deduct any stranded cost for shipped product that doesnt sell (e.g., cost of shipping back).

In case of limited inventory (replenishment with constrained DC inventory, or allocation with finite season buy), shipping inventory to a store for immediate benefit must be balanced against the deferred benefit of holding it back at the DC, where it will be available for future use when well have better information where to send it.

Unifying the logic: The process for performing the optimization for both replenishment and allocation could utilize the same logic (although different economics).

1. Assume that inventory sent to selling locations is available as a shipping unit (SU), which can be one of the following:each: one unit of a single SKUcase pack: multiple units of a single SKUprepack: one or more units of multiple SKUs
2. Evaluate the benefit of sending each SU to each location (if applicable for that location). If the SU includes multiple units or products, the benefit of the SU is simply the sum of the benefits for the constituent units. Note that the benefits below are not the total expected margin or revenue, but the incremental values from the units being considered for replenishment/allocation.For replenishment, benefit = expected CP margin - expected carry cost - expected obsolete costFor allocation, benefit = expected CP revenue - expected stranded cost
3. Allocate one unit of the SU with the largest benefit.
4. Recalculate benefit for that SU (and other affected SUs) at all applicable locations

est benefit.
4. Recalculate benefit for that SU (and other affected SUs) at all applicable locations
5. Repeat the allocation until benefits fall to some arbitrarily small positive value

The logic above is used to calculate orders, not order points. However, an order point calculation algorithm would use the same benefit calculations (2.a), as would a max-order algorithm.

Pros:

1. Consistent algorithm for performing greedy search, with the benefit calculation being the only difference. This would mean one code base that needs to be maintained.
2. More easily handles business constraints/priorities.
3. For replenishment, better for handling non-optimal orders:Limited [DC] inventory availabilityTruck-roundingSpecified push (e.g., prior to a promotion event)

Cons:

ed [DC] inventory availabilityTruck-roundingSpecified push (e.g., prior to a promotion event)

Cons:

1. Either:No direct order point or max order calculationRequires both greedy heuristic as shown above and the order point algorithm if using forward-looking inventory position (FLIP?)
2. Changes for one product would need to be tested for both products. This may not be much of an issue if we can include parameter settings that effectively ignore a new feature.
